summary: A letter from Assistant United States Attorney A. Marie Villafaña to Jeffrey Epstein's attorneys regarding the 'Notification of Identified Victims' process under the Non-Prosecution Agreement. The letter outlines government requests for how victims should be notified, objects to certain proposed language, questions a requirement for Epstein to sign an acknowledgment, and requests information about pro bono lawyers representing victims.

persons.name: A. Marie Villafaña
persons.context: Author of the letter, representing the U.S. Attorney's Office in the Southern District of Florida, communicating with Epstein's defense team about victim notification procedures under the Non-Prosecution Agreement.

persons.name: Jeffrey E. Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the Non-Prosecution Agreement. The letter discusses his obligations and the government's requests regarding victim notifications related to his case.

persons.name: Joseph R. Atterbury
persons.context: One of Jeffrey Epstein's attorneys, listed as a recipient of this correspondence along with Jack A. Goldberger and Jason S. Weiss.

persons.name: Jack A. Goldberger
persons.context: One of Jeffrey Epstein's attorneys, listed as a recipient of this correspondence along with Joseph R. Atterbury and Jason S. Weiss.

persons.name: Jason S. Weiss
persons.context: One of Jeffrey Epstein's attorneys, listed as a recipient of this correspondence along with Joseph R. Atterbury and Jack A. Goldberger.

persons.name: E. Davis
persons.context: Mentioned in a citation to a prior letter from the government dated October 25, 2007, regarding the government not vouching for the veracity of claims by identified individuals.

connections.description: Atterbury is listed as one of Epstein's defense attorneys receiving this legal correspondence.
Goldberger is listed as one of Epstein's defense attorneys receiving this legal correspondence.
Weiss is listed as one of Epstein's defense attorneys receiving this legal correspondence.
Villafaña, as an AUSA, is corresponding with Epstein's legal team regarding the implementation of his Non-Prosecution Agreement.
Villafaña is addressing legal correspondence to Atterbury as part of Epstein's defense team.

events.title: Meeting at AUSA Office
events.description: A meeting occurred at A. Marie Villafaña's office where victim notification procedures and pro bono lawyers were discussed.

events.title: Draft Notification Delivered
events.description: Epstein's attorneys hand-delivered a draft 'Notification of Identified Victims' memorandum to the U.S. Attorney's Office.

events.title: Prior Government Letter
events.description: The government sent a letter to E. Davis stating it does not vouch for the veracity of claims by identified individuals.

keyFacts: The U.S. Attorney's Office objected to a proposed method of notifying Epstein's victims, fearing it could signal a broad notification to numerous alleged victims and potentially position federal authorities as advocates for civil litigation.
The government questioned why Epstein should be required to sign an acknowledgment/waiver related to the victim notifications, arguing it exceeded the terms of the written Non-Prosecution Agreement.
The government requested the names of 'pro bono lawyers' intending to represent identified victims, and details about how they were selected and what communications the Government had with them.
The letter confirms the existence of a 'Non-Prosecution Agreement' between Jeffrey Epstein and the Government, and references a list of 'identified individuals' (victims).

The correspondence reveals ongoing negotiations and legal interpretations between prosecutors and Epstein's defense team regarding the implementation of the plea agreement's victim notification provisions.
